"Twenty veteran warriors commit suicide every day, especially older veterans," said the presidential candidate assumed in the Republican Party during a speech on July 11 in Virginia Beach, where he raised the management of veterans and instituted reforms. We wondered whether the sad suicide number in Trump was correct. His campaign referred to a research in the VA case issued on July 7 before the Agency published this month its most comprehensive report so far on suicides of veterans. The Veterans ' Corps examined about 55 million Veterans ' Registers from 1979 to 2014. It found that in 2014, the last year for which figures are available, 7,403 veterans killed their own lives, or an average of 20 veterans per day. This number is supplemented by a significant estimate of large combatants who stated that an average of 22 veterans were killing themselves every day in 2010. The Alliance has long recognized that this old study was limited, because it was based on veterans living in only 21 states. He was notably absent from California and Texas - two states with a very large population of veterans. The new number of 20 veteran suicides a day is based on records from every state. The Veterans ' Association said that 65% of the ex-combatants who killed themselves in 2014 were 50 years or older, a finding consistent with Trump ' s statement that daily suicides were related in particular to "older veterans." With regard to the context, it should be noted that 75 per cent of the country ' s veterans are 50 years or more. On the other hand, the Attorney General found that younger veterans had the highest rate of suicides. In 2014, the suicide rate among those between 18 and 29 years of age was 77 per 100,000 population. In comparison, the rate of veterans aged 50 to 59 was 39 per 100,000. In all age groups, the Alliance found that the percentage of veterans who spend their lives is much higher than the percentage of adults who never served in the army. For example, the rate of non-combatants aged between 18 and 29 years was 12.8 per 100,000 inhabitants. The rate for non-vegs aged 50 to 59 was 18.6 per 100,000 inhabitants. The suicide rate in 2014 for all ex-combatants was 35.3 per 100,000; the suicide rate for all non-combatants was 15.2 per 100,000. After adjusting to age and gender differences, the Veterans ' Association concluded that the suicide risk for veterans was 21 per cent higher than the suicide risk for adults who did not serve. David Schulkin, Under-Secretary of Health of the Ministry of Public Health, said that the department did not view the new number as a sign of progress. Schulkin said that the average number of daily suicides might decrease because the elderly population of ex-combatants was also decreasing. However, he stressed that the rate of suicide among veterans was rising. The Veterans Association figures show that the rate of suicide among veterans has already increased by 32 per cent since 2001. This compares with an increase of 23 per cent in the non-pretzels rate during the same period. According to the new report, the suicide rate among veterans using VA services has increased 8.8 per cent since 2001, while the suicide rate among veterans who did not use VA services has increased 38.6 per cent. Critics have said that it is pointless to focus on the daily number of suicides experienced by veterans, and that emphasis should be placed on studying the suicide rate of veterans and how it is compared with the rest of the country. At the press conference, Schulkin said that the daily number of suicide rates had become "trained" in a public conversation to the point where the prosecutor had decided to recalculat him for his health.
